div1.p: Taylor discusses the Rockefeller Foundation's strategy of immunization against disease.

div1.head: Letter from John R. Taylor to Philip Showalter Hench, March 2, 1942

opener.dateline:
548 Grand Ave
Upper Darby, Pa.
Mar 2, 1942

div1.p:
Your letter of Feb 26,
received. Can imagine how busy you
are, however when you come to Philadel
phia, will be glad to see you. Will
repeat the telephone where I live
is Hilltop 307-R. The phone is not
in my name, but that of my Cousin
Mary A. Butland.

Glad you have seen my
correction as being an American.
Years ago I visited the Surgeon
Generals office, and also had
2
consultation with Gen. Jefferson
Kean, to have the matter corrected.

I find that Sternbergs last
paper in the Pan American
Scientific Congress of 1915-16 is
in the Mercantile Library of Phila
delphia of which I am a member.
Probably you have seen the book,
if not, you can get it when you come

Have just re-read Sternbergs
.long report in the Annual
Report of the Supervising General
of the Marine Hosp Service
pp 133-239, and it sure is
a creditable one.

Coming back to the question of
immunazation to prevent or eradicate
yellow fever (Gorgas and Guiteras),
it is interesting that 40 years or
more later, the workers of the
Rockefeller Foundation consider
it necessary to adopt immuniz-
ation methods against yellow-
fever.
